abstracts.cdata!:
This Social Assessment (SOA) focuses on
            potential socioeconomic impacts resulting from the
            implementation of the Conservation and Sustainable Use of
            the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System Project in Mexico,
            Belize, Guatemala, and Honduras. It identifies the
            populations who inhabit, and/or enjoy the area's
            ecosystem, in particular the impact of their fishing/tourism
            activities in the barrier reef, to specifically ensure that
            recommendations concerning indigenous/ethnic populations,
            are included in the project design. The first part of the
            SOA describes indigenous/ethnic populations, with a special
            section analyzing the role of women. The second part,
            reviews potential risks, and perceptions of local
            populations regarding recent regional developments.
            Recommendations include supportive indigenous participation
            - Indigenous Development and Participatory Plan - in the
            conservation of the barrier reef ecosystem, focusing on
            specific actions to protect in particular, the livelihoods
            of the poorest, and women. Specific recommendations suggest:
            support income generation alternatives through the promotion
            of ecotourism, and related handicrafts, providing technical
            assistance, and initial subsidies; develop educational and
            vocational training within the formal, and non-formal
            educational system; promote sustainable land uses for
            improved urban, and housing development; improve fishing
            practices within international standards; facilitate
            women's participation through institutional training;
            and, include appropriate indigenous populations' land
            tenure rights within the project's framework.
